description: This family has been included by some authors inthe Plutellidae or in the Yponomeutidae, but the phylogeneticrelationships in this group are still uncertain [Scoble 1992: 238](Scoble1992).
Species of this family are characterised by their particularly long antennae.The family has a world-wide distribution [Scoble 1992: 214](Scoble1992).
This small family consists of two subfamilies, Agonoxeninae andBlastodacninae, of which only the latter is represented in theHolarctic region [Scoble 1992: 247](Scoble1992).
There are about 130 described species, of which most occur in temperate or warm regions [Scoble 1992: 279](Scoble1992).
This small family used to be included in the Oecophoridae, which wasprobably not monophyletic.

Arctiidae include about 11000 species of which about 6000 species occur in the Neotropics, though the family is represented in all major zoogeographical regions. The Lithosiinae, with about 2000 species, are mainly tropical. Ctenuchinae are often treated as a separate family. They also include about 2000 species of mainly tropical distribution. Arctiinae, again with around 2000 species, may not be monophyletic [Scoble 1992: 334](Scoble1992).
Autostichidae is a small family, mainly Indo-Australian. It includes genera that had been placed in Gelechiidae, Xyloryctidae or Symmocidae [Scoble 1992: 243](Scoble1992).

According to [Hodges ](Hodges1978)1978)this family belongs as a separate subfamily in the Coleophoridae. The genus Batrachedra is represented in all the main zoogeographical regions [Scoble 1992: 247](Scoble1992).
This family is sometimes included as a separate subfamily in the Lyonetiidae [Scoble 1992: 239](Scoble1992).
Blastobasidae include more than 300 species. The family is distributed worldwide, but its greatest diversity is in the tropics and subtropics [Scoble 1992: 247](Scoble1992).
The family Bucculatricidae was formerly included in the Yponomeutoidea. It contains only the single widespread genus Bucculatrix [Scoble 1992: 233](Scoble1992).
A small family which is often treated as a subfamily of Oecophoridae.
The family includes about 350 described species, and is represented in all zoogeographical regions, though most species occur in the Orient and Australasia [Scoble 1992: 265](Scoble1992).

The family is cosmopolitan in distribution, but the homogeneous genus Coleophora, in which about 1000 species are described, occurs mainly in the Holarctic region. Second instar larvae construct cases from which they mine leaves or eat seeds [Scoble 1992: 247](Scoble1992).
The family is represented worldwide with about 1200 species, of which many occur in Hawaii [Scoble 1992: 250](Scoble1992).
Approximately 700 species have been described in this family of cosmopolitan distribution [Schoorl 1990](Schoorl1990).
The Crambiform group of the former family Pyralidae s.l. is composed of Crambinae, Schoenobiinae, Scopariinae, Nymphulinae, Evergestinae, Odontiinae, Heliothinae and Pyraustinae.
identification: [Bleszynski 1956](Bleszynski1956), [1957](Bleszynski1957), [1965a](Bleszynski1965a), [De Prins1977](DePrins1977), [Falkovitch1997](Falkovitch1997), [Gaedike1980](Gaedike1980), [Gaedike & Petersen 1985](GaedikePetersen1985), [Goater 1986](Goater1986), [Gozmány 1963](Gozmany1963), [Hannemann1964](Hannemann1964), [Janmoulle1959](Janmoulle1959), [1962a](Janmoulle1962a), [Kuchlein1978](Kuchlein1978), [Kuchlein & Gielis 1982](KuchleinGielis1982), [Kuchlein et al 1980](Kuchleinetal1980), [Marion  1954-1957](Marion19541957][1959-1976](Marion19591976), [Martin 1997](Martin1997), [Opheim 1963](Opheim1963), [Palm 1986](Palm1986), [Petersen1973](Petersen1973), [Petersen, Friese & Rinnhofer 1973](Petersenetal1973),[Petersen & Gaedike 1980](PetersenGaedike1980), [Rinnhofer1975](Rinnhofer1975), [1980](Rinnhofer1980), [Roesler1966](Roesler1966), [1973](Roesler1973), [1993](Roesler1993), [Schwarz1963](Schwarz1963), [Sinev1986](Sinev1986), [Slamka1995](Slamka1995), [1997](Slamka1997), [Soffner1956](Soffner1956), [Speidel1984](Speidel1984), [vanDeurs 1942](vanDeurs1942), [Whalley & Tweedie 1963](WhalleyTweedie1963).

description: Depressariidae are often treated as a subfamily of Oecophoridae, a family which is not monophyletic. It is a cosmopolitan group particularly well represented in the temperate areas [Scoble 1992: 243](Scoble1992).
This family includes only about 20 to 25 species, of which most occur in the Palaearctic region. The family is also represented in North America and in Australia [Scoble 1992: 235](Scoble1992).

Both subfamilies Drepaninae and Thyatirinae have been treated as separate families by several authors. The Drepaninae, with about 800 species, mainly occur in the tropics and subtropics of the Old World. The Thyatirinae, with about 200 species, mainly occur in the Palaearcticand Oriental regions, although the group is represented in all zoogeographical regions except Australia [Scoble 1992: 297](Scoble1992).
Although the family is world-wide in distribution, it is mainly represented in the northern hemisphere [Scoble 1992: 245](Scoble1992).
This family includes a single species, which occurs in the Betula forests ofEurope to the Far East [Scoble 1992: 323](Scoble1992).

This cosmopolitan family now contains 98 described species mainly in the Palaearctic and Australian regions, but it is certain that this is not the true number of representatives of the family, since more detailed investigations in the Ethiopian, Oriental, Australian and Neotropical faunal regions will undoubtedly produce a lot of hitherto unknown taxa [Gaedike 1996b: vi](Gaedike1996b).
Eriocraniidaeare confined to the Holarctic region with less than 30 species described [Scoble 1992: 199](Scoble1992).

A small family which is often treated as a subfamily of Oecophoridae, with about 250 described species, mainly in the genus Ethmia. The group is cosmopolitan with its greatest diversity in the northern Neotropical region [Scoble 1992: 243](Scoble1992).
There are more than 4000 species described in this cosmopolitan family [Scoble 1992: 250](Scoble1992).
The Geometridae are one of the largest families in the Lepidoptera with about 20000 described species. The family is distributed worldwide [Scoble 1992: 290](Scoble1992).
The Glyphipterigidae have a world-wide distribution. In the Palaearctic region the family is mainly represented by the large genus Glyphipterix, with 54 species [Diakonoff 1986: 250](Diakonoff1986).

The cosmopolitan family Gracillariidae includes over 1600 species. The larvae of most species are leaf miners, at least in their early stages.The genus Phyllocnistis is included, though it was often considered a separate family in the past [Scoble 1992: 231](Scoble1992).
nomenclature: Nomenclature according to [Fauna Europeae](http://www.faunaeur.org) except for Caloptilia semifascia which is considered to be a synonym of Caloptilia onustella.

description: There are about 55 described species in this cosmopolitan family [Scoble 1992: 238](Scoble1992).
This cosmopolitan family has relatively few species in Europe, less than 10 [Emmet 1976b: 300](Emmet1976b).
The Hepialidae are distributed worldwide with about 500 species [Scoble 1992: 211](Scoble1992).

The family is represented in all main zoogeographical regions with about 3050 species. No representatives are found in New Zealand [Scoble 1992: 304](Scoble1992). In the West-Palaearctic region there are just over 40 species.
identification: [Bink 1992](Bink1992), [de Jong 1972](deJong1972), [1974](deJong1974), [1978](deJong1978), [Ebert & Rennwald 1991](EbertRennwald1991), [Emmet & Heath 1989](EmmetHeath1989), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1955](ForsterWohlfahrt1955), [Hesselbarth vanOorschot & Wagener 1995](Hesslebarthetal1995), [Higgins & Hargreaves 1983](HigginsHargreaves1983), [Higgins & Riley 1970 + later editions, reprints and translations inseveral languages)](HigginsRiley1970), [Howarth1973](Howarth1973), [Krzywicki1970](Krzywicki1970), [Seitz1906-1909](Seitz19061909) ,[Taymans et al 1993](Taymansetal1993), [Whalley 1981](Whalley1981), [Wynhoff, Made & Swaay 1990](Wynhoffetal1990).

description: The family Incurvariidae is widespread, and although it is particularly diverse in Australia, there are no species known from New Zealand [Scoble 1992: 216](Scoble1992). Twelve species are known to occur in Europe.
The family includes about 2200 described species which are distributed mainly in the Old World tropics [Scoble 1992: 314](Scoble1992).
About 20 species are grouped into this heterogenous family. The genus Lemonia includes 12 species and is present in the Palaearctic region only [Scoble 1992: 397](Scoble1992).
Limacodidae mainly occur in the tropics, but the family is represented in all the zoogeographical regions. About 1000 species have been described [Scoble 1992: 268](Scoble1992).

The Lycaenidae include around 6000 species most of which occur in the Tropics. The subfamily Riodininae is often given family rank. It occurs mainly in the Neotropics. The Lycaeninae have most representatives in the Holarctic region and the Polyommatinae are represented in all major biogeographical regions [Scoble 1992: 313](Scoble1992).
identification: [Bink 1992](Bink1992), [Ebert & Rennwald 1991](EbertRennwald1991), [Emmet & Heath 1989](EmmetHeath1989), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1955](ForsterWohlfahrt1955), [Hesselbarth vanOorschot & Wagener 1995](Hesselbarthetal1995), [Higgins & Hargreaves 1983](HigginsHargreaves1983), [Higgins & Riley 1970 + later editions, reprints and traductions in several languages)](HigginsRiley1970), [Howarth1973](Howarth1973), [Krzywicki1959](Krzywicki1959), [Seitz1906-1909](Seitz19061909), [Whalley1981](Whalley1981), [Wynhoff Made & Swaay 1990](Wynhoffetal1990).

description: The family includes about 2700 described species of which most occur in theOld World tropics [Scoble 1992: 332](Scoble1992).

This family includes about 200 described species and is represented world-wide. Some authors include also Bedellia in this family, representing the separate subfamily Bedelliinae [Scoble 1992: 239](Scoble1992).
Often treated as a subfamily of Tineidae, but sometimes included in Psychidae and even Yponomeutidae. Only 1 species in Europe [Razowski 1996: 39](Razowski1996).

Micropterigidae are probably the most primitive family in the order Lepidoptera, sometimes even treated as a separate order of insects ([Scoble 1992: 192](Scoble1992)). Distributed with 118 described species in all major zoogeographical regions, but many specimens in several collections remain unnamed [Kristensen 1984](Kristensen1984).

The family contains only the genus Mompha of which more than 100 species have been described. Most species occur in NorthAmerica. No representatives are known from Asia, the Orient, and Australia [Scoble 1992: 248](Scoble1992).

The Nepticulidae, cosmopolitan in distribution, comprise about 700 described species but probably many undescribed ([van Nieukerken 1986](vanNieukerken1986)1997 pers. comm.). They include the smallest Lepidoptera with an average wing span of 5-6 mm, in some species it is under 4 mm. The larvae of most species mine leaves [Scoble 1992: 219](Scoble1992).

The family includes well over 21000 described species, is worldwide in distribution, and particularly well developed in the tropics. The classification of the family is still uncertain. Hermiinae may be excluded from the Noctuidae in the future [Scoble 1992: 336](Scoble1992).
identification: [Bretherton Goater & Lorimer 1979,](Brethertonetal1979), [1983](Brethertonetal1983), [Buszko 1980](Buszko1980), [1983](Buszko1983), [1985](Buszko1985), [Fibiger 1990](Fibiger1990), [1993](Fibiger1993), [1997](Fibiger1997), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1971](FibigerWohlfahrt1971), [Goater Ronkay & Fibiger 2003](Goateretal2003), [Hacker et al 2002](Hackeretal2002), [Koch1972](Koch1972), [Kostrowicki1956](Kostrowicki1956), [1959](Kostrowicki1959), [Nowacki1998](Nowacki1998), [Ronkay & Ronkay 1994](RonkayRonkay1994), [1995](RonkayRonkay1995), [Ronkay et al 2001](Ronkayetal2001), [Skinner1984](Skinner1984), [Skou1991](Skou1991).

description: Nolidaeare sometimes considered as a subfamily of the Noctuidae or even the Arctiidae. They are cosmopolitan and include small to very small drab moths [Scoble 1992: 337](Scoble1992).

The Notodontidae include about 3000 species and is distributed in all major zoogeographical regions. Pygaerinae include only the genus Closterawith 43 described species in all the main zoogeographical regions. The composition of the Notodontinae, with at least 200 species, the Phalerinae and the Heterocampinae remains uncertain [Scoble 1992: 331](Scoble1992).

The taxonomic status of certain subfamilies in the Nymphalidae is questionable. The family is represented in all geographical regions with about 6000 species. The Satyrinae, with about 1500 species, are polyphyletic and also the Nymphalidae, with around 3000 species, are probably not monophyletic. The Danainae include about 150 species of mainly tropical distribution [Scoble 1992: 311](Scoble1992).
identification: [Bink 1992](Bink1992), [Ebert & Rennwald 1991](EbertRennwald1991), [Emmet & Heath 1989](EmmetHeath1989), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1955](ForsterWohlfahrt1955), [Hesselbarth vanOorschot & Wagener 1995](Hesselbarthetal1995), [Higgins & Hargreaves 1983](HigginsHargreaves1983), [Higgins & Riley 1970 + later editions, reprints and traductions in several languages](HigginsRiley1970), [Howarth1973](Howarth1973), [Krzywicki1966](Krzywicki1966), [Niculescu1965](Niculescu1965), [Seitz 1906-1909](Seitz19061909), [Whalley1981](Whalley1981), [Wynhoff Made & Swaay 1990](Wynhoffetal1990).

description: The Oecophoridae are particularly well represented in Australia [Scoble 1992: 243](Scoble1992).

The cosmopolitan family Opostegidae was by some authors included in the Nepticulidae as a separate subfamily. There are just over 100 species described, but probably many more remain unnamed [Scoble 1992: 221](Scoble1992).

This family is present predominantly in the tropics, and includes very large, and among the most spectacular species of Lepidoptera ([Scoble 1992: 307](Scoble1992)). There are 573 described species [Collins & Morris 1985](CollinsMorris1985).
identification: [Bink 1992](Bink1992), [Ebert & Rennwald 1991](EbertRennwald1991), [Emmet & Heath 1989](EmmetHeath1989), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1955](ForsterWohlfahrt14955), [Hesselbarth vanOorschot & Wagener 1995](Hesselbarthetal1995), [Higgins & Hargreaves 1983](HigginsHargreaves1983), [Higgins & Riley 1970+ later editions, reprints and traductions in several languages](HigginsRiley1970), [Howarth1973](Howarth1973), [Krzywicki1962](Krzywicki1962), [Niculescu1962](Niculescu1962), [Seitz1906-1909](Seitz19061909), [Whalley1981](Whalley1981), [Wynhoff Made & Swaay 1990](Wynhoffetal1990).

description: Pieridae are represented in all main zoogeographical regions, with about 1200 described species [Scoble 1992: 309](Scoble1992). Well over 40 species occur in the West-Palaearctic.
identification: [Bink 1992](Bink1992), [Ebert & Rennwald 1991](EbertRennwald1991), [Emmet & Heath 1989](EmmetHeath1989), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1955](ForsterWohlfahrt1955), [Hesselbarth vanOorschot & Wagener 1995](Hesselbarthetal1995), [Higgins & Hargreaves 1983](HigginsHargreaves1983), [Higgins & Riley 1970 + later editions, reprints and traductions in several languages](HigginsRiley1970), [Howarth1973](Howarth1973), [Krzywicki1962](Krzywicki1962), [Niculescu1963](Niculescu1963), [Seitz1906-1909](Seitz19061909), [Whalley1981](Whalley1981), [Wynhoff Made & Swaay 1990](Wynnhoffetal1990).

description: The family Plutellidae is by some authors included in the Yponomeutidae. [Kyrki 1990](Kyrki1990) proposed six subfamilies in the Yponomeutidae, but the phylogenetic relationships between them are still uncertain [Scoble 1992: 238](Scoble1992).
The family Prodoxidae is mainly distributed in the Holarctic region, but has also members in southern Argentina and Chile [Scoble 1992: 218](Scoble1992). There are few species in Europe.

This family comprises about 600 species of which about 500 are found in the Old World. The larvae construct prominent larval silken cases in various shapes, covered with a variety of material, such as twigs, leaf debris, and sand grains [Scoble 1992: 229](Scoble1992).
Pterophoridae are represented in all the main zoogeographical regions, with about1100 species [Gielis 1993: 28](Gielis1993).
The Pyraliform group of the former family Pyralidae s.l. contains the subfamilies Galleriinae, Phycitinae and Pyralinae.
identification: [Bleszynski 1956](Bleszynski1956), [1957](Bleszynski1957), [1965a](Bleszynski1965a), [De Prins1977](DePrins1977), [Falkovitch1997](Falkovitch1997), [Gaedike1980](Gaedike1980), [Gaedike & Petersen 1985](GaedikePetersen1985), [Goater 1986](Goater1986), [Gozmány 1963](Gozmany1963), [Hannemann1964](Hannemann1964), [Janmoulle1959](Janmoulle1959), [1962a](Janmoulle1962a), [Kuchlein1978](Kuchlein1978), [Kuchlein & Gielis 1982](KuchleinGielis1982), [Kuchlein Leffef & Kleinpaste 1980](Kuchleinetal1980), [Marion 1954-1957](Marion19541957), [1959-1976](Marion19591976), [Martin 1997](Martin1997), [Opheim 1963](Opheim1963), [Palm 1986](Palm1986), [Petersen1973](Petersen1973), [Petersen Friese & Rinnhofer 1973,](Petersenetal1973), [Petersen & Gaedike 1980](PetersenGaedike1980), [Rinnhofer1975](Rinnhofer1975), [1980](Rinnhofer1980), [Roesler1966](Roesler1966), [1973](Roesler1973), [1993](Roesler1993), [Schwarz1963](Schwarz1963), [Sinev1986](Sinev1986), [Slamka1995](Slamka1995), [1997](Slamka1997), [Soffner1956](Soffner1956), [Speidel1984](Speidel1984), [vanDeurs 1942](vanDeurs1942), [Whalley & Tweedie 1963](WhalleyTweedie1963).

description: This family is distributed in the Palaearctic region, in S. E. Asia and theOrient, and in Australia [Scoble 1992: 234](Scoble1992).

The Saturniidae include about 1300 species. The family is of world wide distribution with most species occurring in the New World tropics and includes some of the largest moths [Scoble 1992: 320](Scoble1992).

The systematic position of this family is still uncertain. There are but few species in the only genus Schreckensteinia, but the genus is known from all zoogeographical regions, except from Australia [Scoble 1992: 276](Scoble1992).
About 370 species have been described in this cosmopolitan family [Scoble 1992: 249](Scoble1992).
The family, of cosmopolitan distribution, comprises about 1000 described species. Most of these occur in the tropics, but many are found in the Holarctic region [Scoble 1992: 260](Scoble1992).
identification: [Baker 1985](Baker1985), [Forster & Wohlfahrt 1960](ForsterWohlfahrt1960), [Hoffmeyer1974](Hoffmeyer1974), [Koch1964](Koch1964), [Latuvka & Laštuvka 1995](LastuvkaLastuvka1995), [Schnaider et al 1961](Schnaideretal1961), [Skinner1984](Skinner1984), [Spatenka et al 1993](Spatenkaetal1993), [1999](Spatenkaetal1999), [Sukhareva 1989d](Sukhareva1989d).

description: The family includes around 1050 species and is distributed worldwide, though most species occur in the tropics [Scoble 1992: 325](Scoble1992).
This family is distributed in the Palaearctic region, in S. E. Asia and theOrient, and in Australia [Scoble 1992: 234](Scoble1992).
Thaumetopoeidae have often been treated as a subfamily in the Notodontidae. They include about 100 species.
About 600 species have been described, which predominantly live in the tropics [Scoble 1992: 282](Scoble1992).

Tineidae is a rather large, cosmopolitan family, in which about 3000 species are described. Unlike most of the other Lepidoptera larvae they do not consume live plant material, but feed on detritus, fungi, lichen or keratine ([Scoble 1992: 226](Scoble1992).
Tischeriidae is a primarily Holarctic family. Most of the species (about 70 species are described) occur in North America. The family is absent from Australasia [Scoble 1992: 223](Scoble1992).
Tortricidae occur worldwide and are most diverse in temperate and tropical regions. About 5000 species have been described, many of them are of economic importance [Scoble 1992: 255](Scoble1992).
identification: [Benander 1950](Benander1950), [Bentinck & Diakonoff 1968](BentinckDiakonoff1968), [Bradley 1959](Bradley1959), [Bradley & Martin 1956](BradleyMartin1956), [Bradley, Tremewan & Smith 1973](Bradleyetal1973), [1979](Bradleyetal1979), [Danilewski & Kuznetzov 1968](DanilewskiKuznetzov1968), [1990](DanilewskiKuznetzov1990), [vanDeurs 1956](vanDeurs1956), [Diakonoff1962](Diakonoff1962), [Diakonoff & Dorst 1982](DiakonoffDorst1982), [Hannemann 1961](Hannemann1961), [1964](Hannemann1964), [Janmoulle1959](Janmoulle1959), [Kennel1908-1921](Kennel19081921), [Kostjuk1980](Kostjuk1980), [Kuznetzov1989b](Kuznetzov1989b), [Larsen & Vilhelmsen 1986-1990](LarsenVilhelmsen19861990), [Obraztsov 1953a](Obratsov1953a), [b](Obratsov1953b), [1954-1957](Obratsov19541957), [1958-1968](Obratsov19581968), [1961-1967](Obratsov19611967), [Opheim 1964](Opheim1964), [1967](Opheim1967), [1968](Opheim1968), [1970](Opheim1970), [Razowski1959](Razowski1959), [1963](Razowski1963), [1969](Razowski1969), [1970](Razowski1970), [1981](Razowski1981), [1983](Razowski1983), [1984](Razowski1984), [1987](Razowski1987), [1991](Razowski1991), [2001](Razowski2001), [2002](Razowski2002).

description: The family has a world-wide distribution, though most of the 800 described species live in the tropics [Scoble 1992: 237](Scoble1992).
This family occurs in the Palaearctic region as fas as North Africa and eastern Russia, and also in N. W. India. It was accidentally introduced in the U.S.A. [Scoble 1992: 238](Scoble1992).

Zygaenidae includes about 800 described species. They are represented in all zoogeographical regions. Most species occur in the tropics, but the family is well represented in the Palaearctic region [Scoble 1992: 264](Scoble1992).
